title: Ticket #3481: Different "idle time" counts for partitionable slots than normal slots
description:
In glideinWMS, we have a DAEMON_SHUTDOWN expression that essentially does: 

(TotalTimeUnclaimedIdle < T1) || (TotalTimeClaimedBusy =!= Undefined && TotalTimeUnclaimedIdle < T2)

This works fine for non-partitionable slots. For partitionable slots, the parent slot always remains in the Idle state, no matter the state of the child slots, so this metric doesn't work. We can hack around it to come up with something usable, but we can't replicate non-partitionable DAEMON_SHUTDOWN behavior with partitionable slots.

Something analogous to TotalTimeUnclaimedIdle may work, but it needs to start counting only when the parent reclaims all the child slot resources (so the entire slot is truly "idle"). We'd also want some parameter to let us know if the parent slot has ever created child slots (analogous to TotalTimeClaimedBusy being defined or not).
remarks:
2013-Sep-24 17:14:09 by danb:
It does still seem useful to have aggregate metrics for slot usage in the startd, but it seems to me the behavior you want is nearly achievable, given the new attributes added in #3712. For detecting if the parent slot has ever created a child slot, one could use TotalJobStarts. There is also TotalRecentJobStarts which is the number of jobs started in the past 20 minutes. One could use that in the DAEMON_SHUTDOWN expression like this: 

    TotalSlots == 1 && TotalRecentJobStarts == 0 && CurrentTime-DaemonStartTime > T1

One problem is a race condition between the time one long-running job ends and the next one begins. During that time, the above expression could become true. The race might be solved if we had TotalRecentJobCompletions instead, assuming it is updated before the expression is evaluated.

2013-Sep-25 14:37:05 by burt:
We could implement it this way, but it makes some of the glideinWMS termination knobs useless if T1 or T2 are greater than 20 minutes. (Typical values are shorter).

Would it make sense if EnteredCurrentState was reset when the parent slot allocated or deallocated child slots? It would be ok (preferred, actually) for me to alter the gWMS semantics to use differential idle time rather than aggregate, something like 

Activity == "Idle" && \
 (RecentJobStarts == 0) && (CurrentTime-EnteredCurrentState) > T1 ||
 (CurrentTime-EnteredCurrentState) > T2

?

2013-Sep-26 10:44:30 by danb:
That seems reasonable to me. Having an explicit attribute that gives the time of the last change in partitioning might be less elegant but safer from semantic drift.

2013-Nov-05 17:06:24 by johnkn:
I propose that we can solve this problem using the same expression for both static and partitionable slots by using the draining timestamps and the new TotalJobStarts attribute. Both of these attributes refer to the state of the entire STARTD, which I think is what you want here. 

DAEMON_SHUTDOWN =
   IfThenElse(TotalJobStarts > 0,
      (time() - ExpectedMachineGracefulDrainingCompletion) > T2,
      (time() - DaemonStartTime) > T1))

Currently ExpectedMachineGracefulDrainingCompletion will continue to advance along with time() when there are no jobs running in the STARTD. But I propose that we fix this behavior. If ExpectedMachineGracefulDrainingCompletion represents the time the last job exited when there are no jobs running (actually no active claims), then it can be used to measure how long the STARTD has been idle.

2013-Nov-06 11:46:27 by burt:
That approach seems OK to me.

2013-Nov-06 17:15:57 by johnkn:
I turns out that the DaemonStartTime attribute isn't in the ad a the time the DAEMON_SHUTDOWN expression is evaluated. (see #4051). Fortunately, SelfMonitorAge has essentially the same information, so we can use that instead. 

DAEMON_SHUTDOWN =
   IfThenElse(TotalJobStarts > 0,
      (time() - ExpectedMachineGracefulDrainingCompletion) > T2,
      SelfMonitorAge > T1)

2013-Dec-05 10:26:25 by johnkn:
draining attributes are: 

    ExpectedMachineQuickDrainingCompletion = 1386261173
    ExpectedMachineGracefulDrainingBadput = 14844
    ExpectedMachineQuickDrainingBadput = 14844
    ExpectedMachineGracefulDrainingCompletion = 1386261173

badput is the amount of time of completed work that would be lost if we drained now.

2014-Sep-15 15:23:20 by marco:
In the expression mentioned there is the attribute TotalJobStarts. In the Machine ClassAds I saw only JobStarts. Are they the same?
